I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China for the Henan Xichuan Integrated Ecological Protection and 
Environmental Improvement Project. 
 
2.  The proposed project will promote environmental improvements and green development in 
ecologically sensitive rural areas by (i) building the capacity of the Xichuan County Government 
(XCG) in environmental planning and management; (ii) promoting soil and water conservation 
through the use of high-level technology, including remote sensing, smart drip irrigation, and 
peripheral rainfall runoff harvesting; and (iii) improving rural waste management and integrated 
urban–rural water supply systems. The project will (i) play a demonstrative role for rural vitalization; 
(ii) promote regional public goods by preserving natural resources and reversing the negative 
impacts of environmental pollution; and (iii) facilitate recovery in the project area from the economic 
impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) through inclusive rural economic development. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The Yangtze River Economic Belt (YREB) and its nine provinces and two specially 
administered municipalities are one of the three key economic growth engines in the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), accounting for more than 40% of the PRC’s population and freshwater 
resources, and 45% of the country’s economic output. While the YREB has benefited from 
extensive development since the 1990s, economic growth in the middle and upper reaches of the 
Yangtze River basin lags significantly behind that in the lower reaches. In many rural areas of the 
YREB, agricultural production and rural livelihoods have lagged behind industrial production and 
urban livelihoods, and income inequality and poverty persist. The majority of rural wastewater, as 
well as other waste, is being directly discharged to waterways, while solid waste, particularly 
plastic waste, is increasing. To promote poverty reduction, rural development, and green and 
inclusive growth, the government formulated the National Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 
2018–2022.1 The strategic plan focuses on agricultural modernization, rural wastewater and 
waste management, rural–urban integration, ecosystem services protection, and governance 
reform. 
 
4.  Project area. Xichuan County, located in Nanyang City, Henan Province, is rural and was 
one of 53 remaining national poverty counties in the PRC in 2020. In 2018, Xichuan County had a 
registered population of 724,600 (including 52.6% males and 47.4% females). Of the 626,100 
permanent resident population; about 56.7% are rural residents, with an average per capita income 
of CNY12,114, which is below the PRC’s average rural per capita income of CNY14,671.2 The 
county’s institutional capacity for environmental planning and management is weak, which is critical 
as it is a source of water for the South-to-North Water Diversion Project.3 The county faces various 
restrictions on development activities mainly because of concerns over degradation of quality and 
quantity of water in the Danjiangkou Reservoir (footnote 3). Xichuan County is also part of the Han 
River watershed in the Yangtze River basin, which has been designated a national key ecological 
 
1  Government of the PRC. 2018. National Strategic Plan for Rural Vitalization, 2018–2022. Beijing. 
2  Bureau of Statistics of Xichuan County. 
3  Danjiangkou Reservoir, located in Xichuan County, was constructed in the 1950s for hydropower and irrigation and 
is one of the largest river impoundments in the Yangtze River basin. The reservoir supplies (through a 1,300 
kilometer-long canal) 13 billion cubic meters of water annually to 14 large- and medium-sized cities in the northern 
PRC, including Beijing and Tianjin, benefiting more than 53 million people.

2 
function zone by the government; it is geologically and ecologically fragile because of extreme soil 
erosion and rocky desertification.4 The frequency and intensity of devastating floods have increased 
from 1990 to 2020 as a result of ecological degradation and climate change.5 Most of the county’s 
rural population lacks basic water and sanitation facilities, which negatively impacts public health 
and the environment. The government needs to adopt a unique, integrated development approach 
that (i) improves the livelihoods; (ii) improves the water quality and river environment; and (iii) 
conserves the ecosystem. Although not officially part of the YREB territory, Xichuan County is part 
of a cluster of counties in the Yangtze River basin surrounding the YREB that contribute to the 
YREB’s development goals.6 
 
5.  Institutional  and  programmatic  issues.  The  unmet  requirements  of  Danjiangkou 
Reservoir protection and ecological conservation has restricted the socioeconomic development 
opportunity  in  the  county,  resulting  in  large  costs.  To  achieve  equitable  development,  the 
government has established an eco-compensation mechanism between water service providers, 
including Xichuan County, and the areas that benefit, including the Beijing and Tianjin municipal 
governments,  but  that  mechanism  is  yet  to  be  institutionalized  with  guidelines.  To  support 
negotiations  regarding  eco-compensation  with  beneficiaries,  XCG  needs  comprehensive 
environmental and ecological protection plans that would ensure a flow of desired ecological 
services, with proper monitoring and evaluation mechanisms and community participation. XCG 
has engaged in ongoing investment in public infrastructure, but these investments have not 
delivered  the  needed  results;  for  example,  construction  of  poorly  planned  rural  roads  has 
exacerbated soil erosion in the ecologically fragile and environmentally sensitive landscape. The 
institutional reform in the PRC in 2018 has not yet been fully reflected in the mandates of local line 
agencies, which require close coordination. The county’s unique geophysical characteristics require 
development planning to be based on sound research across multiple settings in the watershed. 
 
6.  Farmers are reluctant to shift from conventional agricultural practices to environmentally-
friendly, profit-oriented agrobusinesses because of a lack of knowledge and underdeveloped value 
chains—primarily facilities for bulk handling (between harvest and marketing) of perishable products. 
The county lacks farmer cooperatives and agribusiness enterprises that link farmers to markets, 
resulting in a large volume of locally produced vegetables and fruits ending up as waste. The reservoir 
shore is a scenic region, and ecotourism and other initiatives have been promoted that seek to build 
rural  economies  without  harming  the  environment.  However,  implementation  is  hampered  by 
inadequate tourist facilities and difficult access. Recurring floods and the absence of a reliable flood 
early warning system also contribute to poor development performance. A lack of environmental 
awareness  among  farmers,  the  absence  of  local  incentives,  and  marginal  use  of  high-level 
technologies have impaired public service deliveries in the county. XCG needs to strengthen its 
institutional capacity to manage these challenges. 
 
7.  Impaired ecosystem services. About 2,600 square kilometers (km2) (93%) of the county 
area falls in the Danjiangkou Reservoir catchment area. The county has 580 km2 of farmland and 
506 km2 of water surface, while about 65% of the county is comprised of steep mountains; these 
are the site of some 45% of farmlands that are located around the reservoir inlets. More than 50% 
of the county’s area is designated as active rocky desertification area (footnote 4), with very low 
soil formation rates. The average water induced soil erosion rate in this area is estimated at about 
100 ton/hectare (ha)/year or double the threshold of 50 ton/ha/year for high erosion defined by 
 
4  Rocky desertification refers to the hydrogeological processes and human activities that transform karst areas 
(composed of soluble bedrock such as limestone) covered by vegetation and soil into a rocky landscape. 
5  In 2010, flooding caused about CNY658 million in economic losses in the county. 
6  Government of the PRC. 2017. Ecological and Environmental Protection Plan of Yangtze River Economic Belt. 
Beijing.

3 
the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.7 Human interventions, including farming, 
exacerbate rocky desertification in more than 80,000 ha within the county. The average annual 
rainfall in the mountainous area in the county is about 1,300 millimeters, which falls primarily 
during July–October. Fatal flash floods were recorded in 2010, 2011, 2017, and 2018. In 2010 
alone, economic damage in XCG from flash flood events was about CNY658 million, mostly in 
agriculture. Flash flood events are exacerbated by poor drainage infrastructure and clogging of 
natural creeks by sediment in low-lying areas. 
 
8.  The fragile geologic features with poor vegetation and farming on slopes leach nutrients, 
significantly reducing soil productivity and water quality. Grain production in the county fell from 
7.01 ton/ha in 2010 to 4.5 ton/ha in 2019. Farmland is prepared prior to the rainy season, which 
aggravates soil erosion. Some farmlands have been transformed into rocky landscapes that are 
no longer cultivable. About 1,300 kilograms of chemical fertilizer are used annually per ha of 
cultivated land in Xichuan County, which is the highest amount in the PRC.8 An estimated 6,000 
tons of fertilizer is lost from farmland in the county annually, contributing to environmental 
pollution. To solve this and improve farmers’ incomes, XCG converted 21,000 ha of farmland into 
fruit plantations. However, this did not achieve the result because of inadequate irrigation, 
continued soil erosion, and poor operation and maintenance (O&M), including difficulties in 
monitoring land degradation and plant health. Farmers have established their own individual 
groundwater pumps for irrigation and are unaware of current on-farm water and energy efficiency 
levels. As a result, groundwater is overexploited and water quality in the Danjiang and Laoguan 
rivers in the county in the proximity of the Danjiangkou Reservoir has exceeded Class III with high 
nutrient concentrations.9 Industries are not allowed in the county, meaning that farmland and rural 
villages without sanitation and waste management are the main pollution sources. 
 
9.  Rural water services. The sewage network currently covers a portion of urban areas but 
almost none of the county’s rural areas. Total annual wastewater production in the county is 
estimated at about 13 million cubic meters (m3). There are 14 wastewater treatment plants with 
capacity of 100,300 m3/day; the capacity exceeds the current need but serves only a portion of 
urban areas because of their poor spatial distribution and the lack of a wastewater collection 
network. As a result, all rural wastewater and 30% of wastewater from urban areas is being 
discharged into the local rivers without any treatment. Poor sanitation prevails in rural areas with 
many households lacking reliable piped water supply and toilets, prompting many people to resort 
to open defecation. The county produces 202,000 tons of solid waste (and an additional 1,000 
tons of plastic waste) and 128,700 tons of farm waste annually. The solid waste is mostly dumped 
in public spaces and flushed to rivers by surface runoff during rainy season. 
 
10.  Despite experiencing acute water scarcity, the county helps resolve the water scarcity 
problems in the water-deprived northern region of the PRC through the South-to-North Water 
Diversion Project. Much as with sanitation and waste management, most of the county’s rural 
population lack access to a proper water supply. Majority of the population depends on untreated 
private tube-wells or shared spring sources, resulting in poor health and creating a heavy burden, 
particularly for rural women who play a major role in household water provision and waste 
management. About 70% of urban drinking water supply in the county comes from groundwater 
that has been contaminated and/or diminished because of overexploitation, resulting in many dry 
wells. The city’s groundwater quality is far below national standards.10 Poor access to safe water

supplies  and  sanitation  in  combination  with  poor  hygiene  practices  resulted  in  the  rapid 
community spread of COVID-19 in the county in 2020. 
 
11.  Coronavirus disease pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic that began in early 2020 has 
amplified the linkages between biodiversity, public health, and ecosystem-dependent global 
supply chains. The COVID-19 pandemic is being contained in the PRC but remains a risk, 
particularly for rural areas such as Xichuan County, which lacks reliable access to improved water 
and sanitation including wastewater treatment; and where ecological services are critical for 
safeguarding human and environmental health, both locally and regionally. There is growing 
recognition of the need for measures to prevent the spread of infectious diseases in the future, 
and rural vitalization is a key part of the PRC’s recovery from COVID-19; the project is committed 
to contributing to that goal. 
 
12.  Development planning. Poverty, declining water quality, and ecosystem degradation are 
the three most prominent development challenges in Xichuan County. Considering the complex 
nexus among these three key problems in the county and their potential threats to water quality 
and quantity in Danjiangkou Reservoir, XCG urgently needs to adopt an holistic approach to 
development planning that leverages benefits from individual sector interventions and develops 
synergies in support of broader development. To do so, XCG needs to improve its water 
management planning and strategy development as well as enhance institutional coordination 
and technical capacity for more effective implementation. Located in a less-developed region in 
the middle of Yangtze River basin, the county can demonstrate an environmentally sustainable 
growth model that can be replicated in other parts of the river basin, the PRC, and beyond. 
 
13.  Strategic fit. The project will promote green development through investment in natural 
capital in the rural areas. This is consistent with (i) the PRC’s Fourteenth Five-Year Plan, 2021–
2025,11 which aims to reduce the divide between rural and urban areas; (ii) the PRC’s Rural 
Vitalization  Strategy  for  2018–2022  (footnote  1),  which  promotes  poverty  reduction,  rural 
development, and green and inclusive growth; (iii) Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB),12 which places a heavy emphasis on ADB providing value addition through greater 
integration of knowledge in its financial support, prioritizes operations in the areas of tackling 
climate change, building disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability, and  
encourages upper middle-income countries to strengthen institutions and share knowledge; and 
(iv)  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC,  2021–2025, 13  which  emphasizes 
environmentally  sustainable  development,  and  climate  change  adaptation.  It  is  in  line  with 
Sustainable Development Goals 1, 5, 6, and 13.14  
 
B.  Project Description 
14.  The project is aligned with the following impact: rural vitalization with environmental 
improvement and green development along the YREB realized.15 The project will have the

following outcome: water resources management and sustainability of agricultural production

15.  Output 1: Institutional capacity of Xichuan County Government on environmental 
management and knowledge services developed. This output includes (i) institutional support 
to integrate environmental solutions and ecosystem services in local development, including (a) 
drafting  of  ecological  conservation  plans,  and  (b)  facilitating  the  institutional  coordination 
mechanism; (ii) pilot integrated soil erosion mitigation measures at watershed scale, including (a) 
implementation  of  integrated  soil  and  water  conservation  measures  with  different  trials  to 
maximize outcomes, (b) installation of real-time water quality and sediment sampling stations, 
and (c) establishment of a research and development unit; (iii) community-based environmental 
management,  including  (a)  mobilization  of  selected  communities, 17  (b)  pilot  solid  waste 
management at household level, and (c) promotion of ecotourism in selected communities; (iv) 
flood risk management, including (a) enhancement of river monitoring with improved water level 
observation and a surveillance system, (b) improvement of a localized early warning system, and 
(c) development of disaster response capacity; (v) capacity building programs for sustainable and 
eco-friendly  agricultural  practices  including  (a)  raising  knowledge  and  skills  of  farmers  on 
sustainable farming, and (b) establishment of farmers cooperatives with access to digital market 
platforms for selling products, including construction of pilot cold storage facility with the ultimate 
goal of reducing agricultural waste; and (vi) knowledge support including (a) engagement of local 
universities in development research, (b) compilation of best practices, and (c) dissemination of 
knowhow through knowledge platforms, including the Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative 
launched by ADB and the PRC government, and the Natural Capital Lab, currently under 
development.18,19 
 
16.  Output 2: Soil and water conservation practices improved. This output includes (i) fruit 
plantation area development, including (a) installation of smart drip irrigation with automated soil 
moisture  detection  and  digital  irrigation  demand  management  provisions  with  mobile  phone 
applications, (b) construction of a pilot peripheral rainfall harvest system, (c) automatization of a 
fertilizer mixture in drip irrigation systems to reduce fertilizer use, (d) utilization of remote sensing 
technologies, including drones to monitor plant health and soil degradation to ensure improved O&M 
of the fruit plantation area, and (e) improvement of existing digital asset management in big data 
center; and (ii) surface drainage and flood mitigation, including: (a) river rehabilitation with eco-
friendly measures along the Danjiang (Henan–Hubei section) and Xi rivers, and Dongfeng canal, 
(b) introduction of measures against waterlogging, including improvement of road and village 
drainage, and desilting basins, and (c) restoration of natural creeks in low-lying flood-prone areas. 
 
17.  Output 3: Rural water services improved. This output includes (i) rural wastewater 
management  systems,  including  (a)  construction  of  centralized  and  distributed  wastewater 
treatment  facilities,  and  (b)  installation  of  sewage  collection  networks;  (ii)  rural  solid  waste 
management, including construction of a food waste and municipal sludge integrated treatment 
center that will treat biodegradable wastes, and produce biogas to run the center and compost for 
use as fertilizer; and (iii) integrated urban–rural water supply, including (a) construction of water 
intakes at the Danjiangkou Reservoir, (b) construction of water treatment plants, and (c) installation 
of a transmission line from the reservoir to the treatment centers and distribution network.

18.  Lessons. The project design has incorporated lessons from ADB-financed projects and 
international best practices related to soil and water conservation, agricultural development, and 
rural  vitalization,  including  the  importance  of  ensuring  (i)  institutional  arrangements  and 
governance are effective; (ii) O&M is sustainable and includes capacity development; (iii) projects 
incorporate a system for monitoring and evaluating performance; (iv) urban–rural integration; (v) 
nature-based  solutions  and  community  engagement  are  strengthened;  (vi)  high-level 
technologies are used for integrated water resources management; and (vii) the development, 
participation in, and empowerment of farmers and farmer cooperatives.20 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
19.  Value addition by ADB assistance. The project has introduced special and innovative 
features,  including  (i)  an  integrated  development  approach  for  an  economically  poor, 
environmentally sensitive, and ecologically critical region; (ii) research and development on soil 
and water conservation at watershed scale with the provision of proper monitoring and evaluation, 
including the use of advanced technology such as remote sensing (via drone and satellite) to 
monitor soil degradation and plant health; (iii) locally suitable peripheral rainwater harvesting to 
provide gravity flow drip irrigation, reduce energy consumption, and reduce water induced soil 
erosion; (iv) smart drip irrigation with soil moisture measurements, automated fertilizer mixtures, 
and mobile phone-based irrigation demand management; and (v) high-level technologies in utility 
services, including use of global positioning system-based mobile phone applications to track and 
trace  the  solid  waste collection  in  Xichuan  County.  Additionally,  ADB  will  support  XCG  in 
implementing the project in a gender-responsive and socially inclusive manner, importantly 
through a community-based approach. The project’s innovative features and value addition, which 
are aimed at promoting regional public goods, will be disseminated through knowledge products 
and knowledge-sharing events (para. 15) and therefore, can be replicated in other poor rural 
areas in the PRC and ADB’s developing member countries. 
 
20.  Nature-positive recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The project will contribute to 
holistic development in the region by prioritizing investments in natural capital conservation and 
restoration  and  shifting  traditional  investments  toward  valuing  of  nature  and  reduction  of 
inequalities in rural areas. Rural vitalization is a key part of the nature-positive approach to 
recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, aimed at building resilience in the region in the short-, 
medium-, and long-term. The nature-positive approach focuses on investments in natural capital, 
including soil and water conservation and ecosystem restoration. The nature-positive project will 
integrate complementary elements across sectors and stakeholders to address multidimensional 
issues. By promoting a greener, healthier growth model that focuses on nature and strengthens 
institutions and governance, the project will create a safer and healthier environment and reduce 
the risk of epidemics in the future. 
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

22.  The government has requested a regular loan of €170,692,000 million ($200.00 million) 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project.22 The loan will have a 26-year 
term, including a grace period of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
27.  The domestic feasibility studies are technically sound, meet international standards, and 
provide sufficient information on the design’s feasibility. Licensed domestic design institutes 
prepared  all  project  components—considering  local  geophysical,  socioeconomic,  and 
hydrometeorological conditions, as well as anticipated climate change risks (rated medium) in 
accordance with the PRC design guidelines and local regulations. The project considered the

9 
technical and economic viability of alternative solutions such as (i) a centralized or decentralized 
water supply system, (ii) centralized or distributed wastewater treatment plants, (iii) drip or 
sprinkler irrigation, and (iv) concrete lining or gabion wall for erosion control. The studies included 
a demand projection to determine the size and scale of each project component and optimization 
of timescales for project implementation. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
28.  The economic analysis indicated that the project is economically viable, with an overall 
economic internal rate of return of 11.9% and an economic net present value of CNY492.4 million. 
The analysis also confirmed the economic viability of all project components. Sensitivity analysis 
indicated that project viability is robust even under the negative scenarios examined, such as an 
increase in investment costs, a reduction in benefits, and an increase in O&M costs. The full 
economic benefits of the project are expected to be significantly higher, as some effects, such as 
health and ecological benefits, are not easily quantifiable. 
29.  The financial analysis was conducted in accordance with ADB guidelines.24 This included 
financial viability assessments for revenue-generating project components, an assessment of the 
project’s financial sustainability, and an assessment of the financial capacity of the XCG (para. 30). 
Four revenue-generating project components:(i) the forestry and fruit farming development project 
smart irrigation system; (ii) provision of cold storage facilities; (iii) Xichuan County food waste and 
municipal sludge collaborative treatment center; and (iv) Xichuan County water supply for urban and 
rural areas—are financially viable, with financial internal rates of return for the project components of 
1.11% to 5.99%, which compares favorably to the weighted average cost of capital of 0.45% to 0.54%. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
30.  A financial sustainability assessment of XCG considered the fiscal impact of incremental 
recurrent costs, including O&M expenditures and debt service for the project. The analysis 
confirmed the financial sustainability of the project. XCG derives on average 50% of its recurrent 
budget  from  Henan  Provincial  Government  (HPG),  which  is  a  moderate  risk  to  financial 
sustainability. However, the project agreement includes a covenant for adequate O&M funding to 
be allocated by XCG for the project facilities. Further, adequate consulting services will be 
provided during project implementation for institutional and capacity building for environmental 
management and enhanced asset management and O&M of the project facilities. 
 
D.  Governance 
31.  The financial management assessment of XCG was conducted in accordance with ADB 
guidelines.25 The assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk is moderate mainly because 
of XCG’s lack of familiarity with ADB’s financial management policies and procedures. The 
assessment recommended a time-bound action plan, which XCG will implement during the project 
implementation period, to mitigate the identified financial management risks. This will ensure 
capacity of the executing agency’s financial staff, accounting and reporting systems, and internal 
and external audit arrangements will be adequate. Further, XCG’s financial management capacity 
under  the  guidance  of  HPG,  which  is  familiar  with  development  partner-funded  project 
management, will be supported for effective financial management of the project.

32.  The procurement risk assessment confirmed that the XCG, supported by the PMO, has 
adequate capacity to implement ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time), despite its 
lack of experience with internationally financed projects. All procurement will be organized through 
an experienced procurement agent. The project management and capacity development consultants 
will  provide  procurement  and  contract  management  support  to  the  PMO  throughout  project 
implementation. Value for money will be achieved by applying open competitive bidding with national 
advertisement, the single-stage: one envelope (1S1E) bidding procedure, and lowest-evaluated 
substantially responsive bid evaluation modality for majority of packages. This approach can be used 
because the civil engineering and goods procurement requirements of the project are noncomplex 
in nature and can be fully supplied by the domestic market, promoting economy and efficiency in 
procurement.  One  high-level  technology  package  (Support  and  Business  Application  System 
Development and Integration) will be procured through open competitive bidding with international 
advertisement and the use of a scoring system for evaluation to increase the focus on quality and 
solicit offers from an expanded pool of potential suppliers. 
 
33.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, XCG, Xichuan Water Affairs Bureau, Xichuan Housing and Urban–Rural 
Construction Bureau, Xichuan Agriculture and Rural Bureau, Xichuan Tourism Service Center, 
and the Ecology and Environment Protection Bureau. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 21). 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
34.  Poverty and social. The project is classified as a general intervention for poverty reduction. 
The project team, in close coordination with XCG, undertook the poverty and social analysis based 
on stakeholder consultations and socioeconomic surveys. It indicated that about 605,080 people, 
including 89,921 poor or low-income people, will directly benefit from the project. Among them: (i) 
382,827 will benefit from improved water supply; (ii) 471,485 will benefit from improved river 
management, soil and water conservation, and wastewater and solid waste management; and (iii) 
16,491 will benefit from rural infrastructure, smart irrigation, and cold storage facilities. The project 
will provide 1,900 skilled and 3,531 non-skilled employment opportunities to local residents. XGC 
prepared a social development action plan based on the poverty and social analysis, with specific 
targets for the poor and low-income people. XCG consulted local residents and other stakeholders 
during the project preparation, which will be continued during the implementation of the project. 
 
35.  Gender.  The  project  is  classified  effective  gender  mainstreaming,  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming Categories of ADB Projects.26 Women comprise 47.4% of 
the total population in the project area. Women are experiencing (i) extra burden with agricultural 
and household works, (ii) low levels of education and skills, and limited employment opportunities, 
(iii) difficulties associated with water security, and (iv) low participation and leadership in public 
affairs. The project will ensure that women will participate in and benefit from improved services, 
skills training, and employment under the project, including through community mobilization. A 
gender action plan has been prepared based on gender analyses to ensure gender equality, 
covering the following key measures and targets for women: (i) participation in decision-making, 
with  at  least  40%  women  participants;  (ii)  leadership  training  for  women’s  committees  on 
watershed  management  in  one  pilot  village;  (iii)  engagement  of  women’s  committees  in 
governance  of  beautiful  village  initiatives  in  four  pilot  villages;  (iv)  priority  employment 
opportunities, with at least 25% of skilled jobs and at least 35% of non-skilled jobs; and (v)

11 
capacity building and skills trainings in agriculture and ecotourism, with at least 40% women 
participants. Key gender targets have also been included in the design and monitoring framework. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
36.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.27 
 
37.  Environment  (category  B).  An  initial  environmental  examination,  including  an 
environmental management plan (EMP) and grievance redress mechanism, has been prepared 
and disclosed on ADB’s website on 5 October 2020. The initial environmental examination is 
based  on  the  domestic  feasibility  studies  and  environmental  assessments,  site  visits,  and 
stakeholder consultations. XCG, through the PMO, will be responsible for implementation of and 
compliance with the EMP. Qualified full-time environment officers will be assigned to the PMO 
and project implementation units, and a training program has been included in the EMP. The 
project will contribute to environmental benefits, including improved water quality, flood control, 
and solid waste management. Risks include the potential release of contaminants from polluted 
sediments during dredging works, short-term construction impacts (e.g., dust and noise), and the 
use  of  agricultural  chemicals  during  operations.  The  outbreak  of  the  COVID-19  pandemic 
presents a risk to the health of workers and residents. Measures to address these risks have been 
incorporated in the EMP and include procedures for the treatment and disposal of dredge spoil, 
wastewater, solid waste, and sludge; riverbank rehabilitation; and preparation of a COVID-19 
health and safety plan based on best practice guidelines. 
 
38.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project will permanently occupy 2,800.73 
mu of land, of which 491.09 mu is existing state-owned land and 2,309.64 mu is collective land 
that will be acquired permanently.28 A total of 728 households with 2,815 persons will be affected 
by  the  project’s  permanent  land  acquisition,  and  four  households  with  eight  persons  will 
experience more than 10% income loss because of land acquisition. The project will not involve 
any physical house relocation. A total of 1,841.6 mu of land will be used temporarily during 
construction, including 1,146.42 mu of state-owned land and 695.18 mu of collective land 
(affecting  151  households  with  604  persons).  XCG  has  prepared  a  resettlement  plan  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and applicable laws and regulations 
of the PRC. The plan includes adequate measures for compensation and rehabilitation of affected 
people. The plan is based on surveys and consultations with affected people during project 
preparation and will be further updated through detailed measurement surveys and consultations 
during  project  implementation.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  has  been  established  and 
incorporated into the resettlement plan. Due diligence was conducted on existing facilities, 
confirming that there are no outstanding and legacy issues from prior land acquisition.  There are 
no outstanding issues on existing leases; and a land use rights transfer framework has been 
prepared for voluntary land use agreements to be completed during project implementation. XCG 
has the capacity to implement domestically funded projects, and its capacity to implement the 
resettlement  plan  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  will  be 
strengthened by the project consultants. An external agency will be engaged to monitor and 
evaluate the implementation of the resettlement plan and submit semiannual reports to ADB. 
 
39.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project is not expected to impact distinct and 
vulnerable communities of indigenous peoples or ethnic minorities. There are Hui, Man, and

IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
41.  The government and XCG have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and disbursement 
as described in detail in the PAM (footnote 21) and loan documents.

which are set forth in the draft loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
43.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of €170.69 
million ($200,000,000) to the People’s Republic of China for the Henan Xichuan Integrated 
Ecological  Protection  and  Environmental  Improvement  Project, from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 26 years, including a grace 
period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The proposed project will promote environmental improvements and green development in ecologically sensitive rural areas by (i) building the capacity of the Xichuan County Government (XCG) in environmental planning and management; (ii) promoting soil and water conservation through the use of high-level technology, including remote sensing, smart drip irrigation, and peripheral rainfall runoff harvesting; and (iii) improving rural waste management and integrated urban–rural water supply systems.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated May 2021 is provided for the ADB project 53053-001 in the People’s Republic of China.
metadata.Title: Henan Xichuan Integrated Ecological Protection and Environmental Improvement Project: Report and Recommendation of the President
